Instrument_PDS3.instrument_desc:
Instrument Overview ===================
The Agile imager was used to acquire images of the Moon and other reference objects at a high cadence with zero latency between frames.
Agile is one of several imagers available on the ARC 3.5-m telescope. In the latter half of 2009 Agile was installed at its own permanent Nasmyth port, which means it is always mounted and ready to use with an appropriate rotation of the telescope tertiary mirror.
Agile is a high-speed time-series photometer based on the Argos camera at McDonald Observatory (as described in Nather and Mukadam, 2004). Agile is comprised of a Princeton Instruments Micromax camera and a 1024 x 1024 frame transfer CCD with a pixel size of 13 micrometers. Coupled with a focal reducer on the APO 3.5 meter telescope, Agile has a 2.5' x 2.5' field of view with an unbinned plate scale of 0.145'' per pixel. Agile has an average read noise of 6.9 electrons RMS and a dark current of 6.8 counts sec-1 pix-1. Its exposure start times and durations are slaved to GPS synchronized pulses, providing timing control accurate to within 1 millisecond. Continuous frame transfers result in zero latency time between exposures. An exposure time of 0.3 seconds is possible with 3 x 3 binning; the pixel scale with 3 x 3 binning is 0.435''/pixel. The optical system includes a six-position spectral filter and neutral density filter wheel.
For complete information see http://www.apo.nmsu.edu/ and NATHER&MUKADAM2004.
